obvious that a vast amount of diversity in the arrangement of the
cells of the shell, and of the segments of the animal may present itself;
and that one after another of the characters which at first seem most
clearly marked and therefore most distinctive, may be shaded off
(so to speak) in such a manner that a <u>complete transition is established</u>,
sometimes even in a single disk, between the simple and complex types.
Such a transition is exhibited by the specimen of which a vertical
section is figured in Plate VII, Fig 4; for it is obvious that the central
portion of this disk (<u>a.b</u>) is so exactly conformable to the simpler type,
that if this growth had stopped at the twenty third zone, it would have
undoubtedly been regarded as an unusually large example of that form.
So many variations present themselves, in the development of the
different parts of the more complex type, that it will be desirable
to <s>consider</s> describe them under a distinct head (Sect IV); and when these
shall have been duly considered, I think that the doubt as to
the specific identity of the simpler and more complex forms will
be done away.

<s><u>III Physiology</u> </s>
<s>34. Of the mode in which the Nutritive process is carried on in the
Orbitolite, our imperfect acquaintance with their living habits leaves</s>
